Posts.Title: Rise in PSA with last positive biopsy 3 years ago

Posts.Content: My Active Surveillance Dr. at MSKCC who is also a surgeon, does MRI guided biopsies. My last one was 12 cores but he put more emphasis on a suspicious area seen on the MRI. He is hoping to get to the point where they only biopsy the suspicious area reducing the number of cores. The increase in the number of cores, increase the chance of infection and potential nerve damage (I was told).

Posts.Title: Deciding on course of therapy - Surgery vs Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: Dave, You might want to consider having a 3T MRI and see what the results are or even a MRI guided biopsy. The MRI guided biopsy are much more accurate then a standard TRUS. At Sloan Kettering they are now doing MRI's before any biopsy. The biopsy would only be done if the results of the MRI warrant it. Let us know the results of your 2nd biopsy. If only one or two cores are found, Gleason 6 you might want to consider Active Surveillance. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: 3 weeks Post Op

Posts.Content: Bassman, What was your PSA and details on your first biopsy? To my surprise I was diagnosed with PCa in February at age 51. One core positive out of 12, Gleason 6. I am very health conscious, always ate healthy, little red meat, a lot of fruits and vegetables. Also liked to exercise 3-5 times a week. Yet there are people eating fast food, steaks and soda every day who do not come down with cancer. Maybe it is in ones jeans and you cannot hide from it. Maybe my cancer would be much worst if I ate less healthy. I has a 2nd biopsy in September which came back negative. My Oncologist said I still have cancer but probably a small amount. I will continue on Active Surveillance.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Biopsy Negative

Posts.Content: Blank, My suggestion is before you do anything I would get a second opinion on the reading of your biopsy slides. There have been times when the Gleason score is either downgraded or upgraded. If your PCa is determined to be a Gleason 6, this would make a big difference. I would recommend going to Johns Hopkins, Memorial Sloan Kettering or Bostwick Labs. You can google "getting second opinion on Biopsy" to get more info. Just my two cents.

Posts.Title: Incontinence after Dr.Samadi surgery

Posts.Content: Dave, Since you are considered low risk, take your time and do as much research as possible. When I was diagnosed two years ago my Dr. wanted me to decide on a treatment in a week. I decided on radiation (IMRT). Luckily I changed my mind last minute and boy am I glad. Over the last 2 years I have monitored my PSA and had two MRI's. Just this week I had a MRI guided biopsy which takes a biopsy sample from the suspicious tumor. This increases the accuracy of the biopsy, no guessing if they missed a higher grade cancer. I bring this up to point out you have to be your own advocate and educate yourself.

Posts.Title: Free PSA question

Posts.Content: Stuart, I would wait and do the MRI guided biopsy. If you research it on the web you will see they are much more accurate. My Dr. at Memorial Sloan Kettering only does MRI guided biopsy's. If you do a standard biopsy and nothing is found you'll be in the same boat. I think you need to find a Dr. who specializes in MRI guided biopsy's. Keep us posted and best of luck.

Posts.Title: Your input needed. Do an MRI guided Biopsy or Just Biopsy if delay in getting MRI

Posts.Content: Carol, I was 51 (now 52) when diagnosed in February with PCa. 1 core out of 12, Gleason 6, PSA 4.0. Through my research and speaking with doctors I was informed that PCa is slow growing and I have plenty of time to decide on my treatment method. Johns Hopkins, Memorial Sloan Kettering and others are now informing PCa patients about over treatment for low grade cancer. These organizations are HIGHLY respected in the field of cancer research and I am trying not to be influenced by people on these forums who made there decision on fear and uncertainties. AS programs are very similar throughout the world, PSA and DRE every 3 months and a biopsy once a year. Under this program there is a very good chance of detecting if the cancer is growing and needs treatment. This is just my opinion. I recommend taking your time and do as much research as possible.

Posts.Title: Further action following testing for P.C

Posts.Content: Leo, If it was me I would get a psa test in 6 months. If it goes down or stays the same you still need to monitor it. If it goes up you need to find the cause. A psa of 5 is a bit high for someone in their 50's.
Posts.Signature: Age 51 when, diagnosed,2/12 Psa 5.3 and 3.5, 3/12 PSA 3.9 Biopsy 1 core of 12, 23% gleason 6 6/12 Psa 4.0, Free PSA 10% 9/12 2nd biopsy, all 12 cores negative. 2/13 PSA 4.2 5/13 PSA 4.2 8/13 PSA 4.3 11/13 PSA 4.6 2/14 PSA 5.3 2/14 MRI Guided biopsy at MSKCC, 12 cores negative 8/14 PSA 5.7 2/15 PSA 6.3 8/15 MRI, PSA 7.04, 2/16 PSA 8.05 MRI and biopsy scheduled for August 2016
